Author: dfranke
Content: If this had existed a decade ago I might have ended up as an EE.  As a kid I had just as much interest in electronics as I did in programming, but having no money and growing up in suburban hell with no decent electronics stores within driving distance, I couldn't pursue it.  I think this is the most promising YC startup to date (based on what I know about them when they launch; obviously Reddit is successful with probability 1).

Author: danielha
Content: I'm not exceedingly familiar with too many VC names at this point, but I'd second Ram Shriram. Dave Cheriton would also be a great person on your side, but he's more of an advisor. For VC, John Doerr from KCP&B comes to mind.

Author: amichail
Content: I don't know of a good solution, but I think the problem is worth exploring given the importance of choosing a compelling domain name.

Author: Harj
Content:
If you could have anyone, VC or angel, invest in your startup who would it be (YC excluded)?

For me I think it'd probably be either Ron Conway or Ram Shriram - they seem to be the closest thing there is to a bridge between traditional angel money and VC.

Author: danielha
Content: It's one thing to have a novel idea. But do you have a competitive advantage in the form of, say, a patent? Discuss!

Author: danielha
Title: Question for founders: Do you own your technology?

Author: danielha
Content:
I enjoy playing devil's advocate, so bear with me. :)

What community can you trust to give you proper feedback on a domain name? If it's a community of people also scouring for domains, what if they decide to hide their approval?

Author: danielha
Title: 2006 Startup school notes by William Manegold

Author: ed
Content: Second the thread archive. I heard there was a secret YC video posted in an old thread but can't find it anywhere! :(

Author: danielha
Content: I liked this article and I think it's applicable to many other things besides programming.

Author: amichail
Content: Maybe some way could be introduced to reserve the domain name proposed temporarily during this testing period.

Author: danielha
Content: I'll be the one that points out the obvious problem in that. After realizing the strength of a domain proposal, what stops another from quickly grabbing that name? I'm assuming this is all prior to you actually registering the name yourself, since you'd sink a lot of money into purchasing every proposal you can muster up.

Author: lucks
Content: It looks like there might not be database migrations for Turbogears based on this post: http://news.ycombinator.com/comments?id=2397 . (Note that the post specifically refers to SQLAlchemy, which will be used in future versions of TurboGears.)
